awd_titl_txt: Integration of Teaching Co-ops in a Master's of Education Program for STEM Teachers
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, a team from the Colleges of Arts & Sciences, Education, and Engineering at Marquette University, partnering with Brown Deer School District and West Allis-West Milwaukee School District, as well as with a number of schools, will recruit and prepare science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) majors as post-baccalaureate Noyce Scholars for careers in teaching secondary mathematics or science. The project will build on a prior Noyce project (DUE award 0934442) that was focused on undergraduate Noyce Scholars and that successfully integrated teaching cooperative education experiences (intensive field experiences) with education pedagogy and STEM content knowledge. By the end of the five-year project, 28 Noyce Teachers will have begun their teaching careers in high-need local education agencies in the greater Milwaukee area.

This project will develop methods for building a community of graduate students, K-12 school teachers and administrators, and university faculty focused on STEM education across the traditional boundaries of departments, colleges, schools, and school districts. Use of the co-op model will provide the Noyce Scholars with extensive hands-on, career related work experience and the opportunity to develop professionally as well as academically. The goals of the project will include: (1) build on knowledge gained through the prior successful undergraduate Noyce program to develop a STEM teacher preparation providing a graduate level program for individuals with a B.S. in a STEM discipline; (2) provide an exceptional STEM master's level teaching licensure program specifically targeted to address the challenges of high-need schools; and (3) mentor and retain these highly qualified STEM teachers through various networking, support, and professional development activities

por.por_cntn:
This project developed a 14-month Master of Education in STEM Teaching program to prepare STEM graduates and career changing STEM professionals to teach in grades 6-12 mathematics and science classrooms in high-need schools. The project provided a model from which teacher educators in other universities can draw on to develop a post-baccalaureate teacher preparation program to prepare high quality mathematics and science teachers. Over the course of five years, 18 STEM graduates and career changing STEM professionals completed the program and received endorsement to teach in grades 6-12 mathematics and science classrooms.

We built our 14-month graduate program on a teaching co-op model in which STEM content knowledge, pedagogical instruction, and direct work with middle and high school students in field experiences and student teaching were integrated into semester-long experiences. In Teaching Co-op 1, scholars focused on student learning and development as well as exceptional and diverse student needs while participating in our Educational Opportunity Upward Bound Mathematics and Science Program. During Teaching Co-op 2, scholars learned about ambitious STEM instruction while completing an extensive field experience in a mathematics or science classroom. Teaching Co-op 3 engaged scholars in their practice during a traditional student teaching experience in mathematics and science classrooms. Finally, in Teaching Co-op 4, scholars focused on professional issues in STEM education as they completed an action research project to prepare to begin their own practice.

Our program utilized ambitious STEM instruction, an approach to teaching that supports all students, regardless of race, ethnicity, gender, identity, or socioeconomic status, in learning STEM content with understanding. Ambitious STEM instruction supports students in high-need schools by fostering student sense making, maximizing student engagement, and maintaining high standards for academic rigor.  

We found that our Noyce program created the opportunity to provide a more coherent preparation by utilizing research-based practices related to ambitious STEM instruction. As Noyce scholars learned about ambitious STEM instruction, they developed a common language to describe their practice, thus fostering their capacity to conceptualize a practice that aligns with national mathematics and science standards and supports student learning in high-need schools. We also found that rehearsing ambitious STEM instruction played a significant role in supporting Noyce scholars in analyzing their own ability to enact ambitious practices in mathematics and science classrooms. Finally, our experience as instructors and leaders in the program provided a context in which we conceptualized a model of teacher development in relation to ambitious STEM instruction. Our model of ambitious STEM instruction development provided a way of thinking about teaching in terms of both developmental trajectories and foundational definitions of teaching practice. The model suggests that multiple pathways to development of expert ambitious STEM instruction are likely and that Noyce scholars completing our program moved more quickly toward expert in their development of ambitious STEM instruction.

The teaching co-op model provided a significant vehicle for supporting Noyce scholars in developing ambitious STEM practices. Central to this model are (1) scaffolding from university methods instructors and field-based cooperating teachers throughout the program, and, (2) opportunities to rehearse (methods courses), implement (field experiences and student teaching), and reflect on (methods courses) ambitious STEM instruction throughout the program. We assert that through these experiences, Noyce scholars began to utilize ambitious STEM instruction in their approach to teaching. While the cohort is small and implications are therefore limited, our program provides one promising pathway for preparing teachers that are strong in STEM content and capable of implementing this type of practice in powerful ways to students in high-need schools.

Teacher educators and researchers can use the results of the research and associated techniques involved in our Noyce program to inform their work in designing teacher preparation programs that support prospective teachers in learning about and using ambitious STEM instruction.

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2023
Modified by: Leigh A Van Den Kieboom

    van den Kieboom & McNew-Birren
    Public Domain
    Leigh A Van Den Kieboom
    Ambitious STEM Instruction Development Model
